title: An introduction to the EJSCREENbatch tool
text: access latest version package, simply install EPA’s Github Repo using devtools package: Next load package (others essential vignette): Users note package installed certain functions called, EJSCREEN ACS data downloaded saved package’s library folder. users hyper-conscious local disk space, making default EJfunction() call using recent releases EJSCREEN/ACS data locally save files roughly 1GB size. users intend perform screening analyses using older multiple vintages EJSCREEN/ACS data, less disk space may required.
code: # Import EJSCREENbatch package  library(devtools) install_github(repo = "USEPA/EJSCREENbatch") library(EJSCREENbatch) library(tidyverse) library(data.table) library(DT)

title: An introduction to the EJSCREENbatch tool
text: run tool, user supplies input location data. Since batch tool, data can (!) include several input locations. locations points space (.e. lat/long coordinates emitting facility), shapes (.e. set linestrings representing streams/rivers polygons representing wetlands, municipal boundaries, air pollution plumes), waterbody identifier NHDPlus database (). illustrative purposes, work vignette using dataset containing latitude/longitude outfall coordinates set meat poultry processing (MPP) facilities Great Lakes region. MPP outfalls feed directly US’s water network, serve “locations interest” (LOIs) vignette’s sample EJ analysis. One important technical item: location inputs must fed package functions either (1) simple feature (sf) data.frame point/line/polygon shapes (2) list catchment common identifiers (COMIDs). See sf package documentation primer using spatial data R nhdplusTools package overview catchment ID data structure. illustrative sense geographies screened, map location inputs . next section, draw spatial buffers around locations extract demographic environmental data EJSCREEN’s national database.
code: ### MPP facilities pulled from stable URL -- only those mpp <- data.table::fread('https://ejscreenbatch-data.s3.amazonaws.com/dmr_mpp_facilities_2019.csv') %>%   dplyr::filter(State %in% c('IL','IN','MI','OH','WI')) %>%   sf::st_as_sf(coords = c('Facility Longitude', 'Facility Latitude'), crs = 4326) # Visualize locations of MPP facilities: library(ggplot2) ggplot() +    geom_map(data = map_data('state') %>%               dplyr::filter(region %in% c('illinois','indiana','michigan',                                          'ohio','wisconsin')),            map = map_data('state') %>%               dplyr::filter(region %in% c('illinois','indiana','michigan',                                          'ohio','wisconsin')),            aes(x = long, y = lat, map_id = region),            color = 'black',fill = NA) +   geom_sf(data = mpp, color = 'red') +   theme_minimal()

title: An introduction to the EJSCREENbatch tool
text: now demonstrate batch tool’s implementation. foundation package built around EJfunction(), heavy lifting data compilation, cleaning, spatial computation. Based user-provided input data options selected, buffers drawn around locations, data EJSCREEN ACS extracted compiled areas. function’s primary role return data.frames containing raw summarized information. provide meaningful systematic comparisons across locations, data.frames returned EJfunction() report national state percentiles addition raw demographic environmental indicators.

title: An introduction to the EJSCREENbatch tool
text: begin running simple, EJ screening call set location coordinates. EJfunction() accepts sf data.frame data input.1 Note example function call may take several minutes run machine depending bandwidth processor speed. proximity analysis draws simple buffer 1 mile (buffer = 1) around location, extracts/returns raw EJSCREEN data CBGs intersect buffer area. default (suggested) GIS method (raster = T), function also returns location-level summary data.frame similar spirit data returned EJSCREEN mapper API. raster-based population weighting approach differs slightly EJSCREEN mapper’s rely NASA’s SEDAC population grid, EJSCREEN weights populations using Census block centroids. align EJSCREEN population buffering approach, users can set option (raster = F) default, function returns 3 outputs user’s work environment: .EJ.data: list sub-objects result screening (see details) data.tog: sf data.frame raw EJSCREEN selected ACS demographic data U.S. states Puerto Rico. raster_extract: raster containing population counts North American continent. data.tog raster_extract kept memory design ease additional runs EJfunction() user wish fine-tune analysis incorporate custom data visualization analyses appropriate.
code: # A simple application of EJfunction() my.EJ.data <-  EJfunction(mpp, buffer = 1, raster = T)

previous_headings: Compiling data: using EJfunction() > An initial run
title: An introduction to the EJSCREENbatch tool
text: object returned .EJ.data list two data sub-objects: First, CBG-level data block groups within designated 1-mile buffer proximity returned EJ.cbg.data.2 CBGs identified ID column; note CBG population estimates data.frames net population fraction fall within LOI’s buffer. ensures double counting population occurs user elect sum head counts across impacted CBGs. data may interest users two reasons. (1) users want characterize demographics environmental characteristics across LOIs, data provide opportunity calculate statistics using population-weighted averaging sum total population count living within buffers LOIs. (2) cases buffers overlapping, users can use CBG-level data develop within-LOI, “neighborhood”-level analyses populations may affected policy. flavor data, can explore data.frame , filtered include block groups fall within distance buffers MPP facilities Wisconsin. EJSCREEN variable names definitions can downloaded .
code: names(my.EJ.data) #> [1] "EJ.cbg.data" "EJ.loi.data"

previous_headings: Compiling data: using EJfunction() > An initial run
title: An introduction to the EJSCREENbatch tool
text: Second, location-level summaries returned EJ.loi.data. LOI-level information analogous report returned EJSCREEN’s online point--click mapper interface. , rather compiling results single location, data returned tidy data.frame format batch locations. location uniquely identified variable shape_ID.data.frame includes national state percentiles, well population-weighted raw values EJSCREEN indicator key demographic variables ACS. , explore summary return MPP facilities.

title: An introduction to the EJSCREENbatch tool
text: user able specify several alternative settings compiling data EJfunction(). include: buffer distance(s) within select proximate CBGs. Users can modify distances (miles) using buffer argument. Input value(s) must numeric can vector user interested running analyses several bandwidths. buffer GIS method used apportion population CBGs overlap LOI buffer’s boundary. Users specify via raster argument. default setting raster = T. package currently built use NASA’s Socioeconomic Data Application Center (SEDAC) 1km x 1km raster. package’s buffering method relies 2010 vintage population count raster EJSCREEN vintages 2021 earlier, 2020 vintage recent years. alternative set option raster = F: result use EJSCREEN Mapper’s methodology. EJfunction() download census block centroid coordinates use calculate fraction boundary CBG’s population falls within LOI’s buffer. fraction used population-weight demographic environmental statistics displayed EJ.loi.data. data vintage used analysis, cases user like perform retrospective screening using older versions EJSCREEN corresponding ACS data. option set data_year parameter using numeric value. Currently, EJSCREENbatch allows vintages 2020 later. state screen, cases user wants restrict analysis single state. set state argument, using state’s designated two letter code.
code: # An example run with multiple buffer distances: my.EJ.data.multibuffer <- EJfunction(LOI_data = mpp,            buffer = c(1,3,5)) # An example run using the census block centroids to apportion buffer population. my.EJ.data.block <- EJfunction(LOI_data = mpp,                                     buffer = 1,                                    raster = F) # An example run using EJSCREEN data from 2021. my.EJ.data.2021 <- EJfunction(LOI_data = mpp,                                 buffer = 1,                                data_year = 2021) # An example run restricting the screening only to the state of WI. my.EJ.data.state <- EJfunction(LOI_data = mpp,                                 buffer = 1,                                state = 'WI')

title: An introduction to the EJSCREENbatch tool
text: previous screening analyses using EJfunction() can also completed using water-feature-based buffering. package leverages surface water network established National Hydrology Dataset (NHD), incorporates NHD, National Elevation Dataset, National Watershed Boundary Dataset. Flowlines catchments (watersheds) context therefore refer established NHDPlusV2 (medium resolution). Users note catchments smaller area HUC12s. leverage package’s water-based screening capabilities, users can supply either sf data.frame point coordinates list catchment IDs (COMIDs) EJWaterReturnCatchmentBuffers() function.

what: Creating flowline shapes with an sf data.frame
title: An introduction to the EJSCREENbatch tool
text: Using MPP outfall data, example, can call following script order return sf data.frame flowlines shapes reaching 25 miles downstream outfalls. Underneath hood, function identifies catchments lie within specified distance - downstream (river miles) starting locations. function creates shapefile starting location’s associated flowline catchments. user can modify two parameters: ds_us_dist set numeric value determine distance - upstream flowline run. ds_us_mode set determine whether flowline shape returned run downstream along main stem (‘DM’), downstream including diversions (‘DD’), upstream along main stem (‘UM’) upstream along tributaries (‘UT’). returned list EJWaterReturnCatchmentBuffers() contains 2 items: flowline_geoms nhd_comids. former sf data.frame, containing user’s original input data updated linestring geometries LOI’s flowline. latter list COMIDS LOI passes. envision COMID lists highly useful supplemental analyses using EPA water data products built NHDPlus network. illustrate returned output, flowlines MPP facilities Great Lakes Region mapped code block :  dark blue points map represent original coordinates MPP dataset; lighter blue flowlines moving away points show resulting linestring geometry produced output. sf data.frame flowline geometries (mpp.flowlines$flowline_geoms) hand, now straightforward call EJfunction() return environmental demographic screening data buffered areas 25 miles downstream MPP outfalls: code block draws 1-mile buffer around flowlines. list data.frames returned EJfunction() identical structure shown . worthwhile explore differences demographic/environmental characteristics result taking water-based buffering approach rather conventional circular buffer.
code: mpp.flowlines <- EJWaterReturnCatchmentBuffers(mpp,                                ds_us_mode = 'DM',                               ds_us_dist = 25) ggplot() +    geom_map(data = map_data('state') %>%               dplyr::filter(region %in% c('illinois','indiana','michigan',                                          'ohio','wisconsin')),             map = map_data('state') %>%               dplyr::filter(region %in% c('illinois','indiana','michigan',                                          'ohio','wisconsin')),            aes(x = long, y = lat, map_id = region),            color = 'black',fill = NA) +   geom_sf(data = mpp.flowlines$flowline_geoms,           color = 'blue',           size = 3) +   geom_sf(data = mpp,           color = 'darkblue') +   theme_minimal() my.EJ.data.flowlines <- EJfunction(mpp.flowlines$flowline_geoms, buffer = 1, raster = T)

title: An introduction to the EJSCREENbatch tool
text: Lastly, possible successfully call EJWaterReturnCatchmentBuffers() non-sf data.frames one specific case. user wishes run water-based screening analysis data.frame “comid” column holds (numeric) COMIDs LOI, function successfully return downstream flowlines COMID lists.

title: An introduction to the EJSCREENbatch tool
text: users like explore spatial data visually, EJMaps() function creates interactive map U.S. displays user’s locations interest. Points/lines/polygons shaded based number indicators screening percentile threshold, allowing users easily identify locations may good candidates outreach efforts /quantitative qualitative analysis. map’s interactive, point click functionality also renders pop-tables share summary data locations interest. Values presented pop-table percentiles, meant ease comparison national state-level context. indic_option parameter controls whether EJMaps()’s color shading scheme summarizes environmental demographic indicators separately summarizes indicators together; geography parameter designates whether national state percentiles used compare threshold. default threshold set 80, suggested EJSCREEN technical guidance, users can modify threshold suit mapping needs. user’s input data includes column identifies LOIs (e.g. facility location names), facil_name parameter can set equal column’s name (string format). Please note map visualization simple starting point regulatory screening analysis users highly encouraged produce figures tables tailored locations interest.
code: EJMaps(input_data = my.EJ.data.flowlines,         geography = 'US',         indic_option = 'total',        facil_name = 'Facility Name')[[1]] #> Joining with `by = join_by(shape_ID)`

title: An introduction to the EJSCREENbatch tool
text: Finally, EJSCREENbatch package canned function allows users make direct calls EJSCREEN API using sf data.frame numeric distance (miles) inputs. function loops API calls, LOI--LOI, mirroring batch ethos used EJfunction(). function, EJSCREENBufferAPI(), return data.frame containing full “firehose” variables provided EJSCREEN. includes standard EJ environmental demographic indicators, well CBG-level indicators health disparities, climate change burden, critical service gaps, richer set demographic information. 500 variables returned API; see EJSCREEN map descriptions details. function may particularly useful cases LOI-level screening data needed. EJSCREEN’s API terribly fast, however, users expect need patience plan streamline returned data.frame usable content analytics.
code: my.EJ.data.api <- EJSCREENBufferAPI(input_data = mpp.flowlines$flowline_geoms,                                     dist = 1) names(my.EJ.data.api) #>   [1] "NPDES Permit Number"          "FRS ID"                       #>   [3] "Facility Name"                "City"                         #>   [5] "County"                       "State"                        #>   [7] "HUC 12 Code"                  "Watershed Name"               #>   [9] "SIC Code"                     "Pollutant Name"               #>  [11] "Substance Registry System ID" "CAS Number"                   #>  [13] "Average Daily Flow (MGD)"     "Major/Non-Major Status"       #>  [15] "Contains Potential Outliers?" title: Authors and Citation
text: Ahmed Rachid El-Khattabi. Author, maintainer. Morgan Teachey. Author. Adam Theising. Author.

title: Authors and Citation
text: El-Khattabi , Teachey M, Theising (2023). EJSCREENbatch: EJSCREEN batch tool. R package version 2.0.1.
code: @Manual{,   title = {EJSCREENbatch: EJSCREEN batch tool},   author = {Ahmed Rachid El-Khattabi and Morgan Teachey and Adam Theising},   year = {2023},   note = {R package version 2.0.1}, }

title: EJSCREEN batch tool
text: 8/18/2023 Version 2.0.1 now available! version simplified EJfunction()’s input requirements deprecated several secondary data visualization functions. streamline initial EJ analysis efforts multiple locations interest, EJSCREENbatch R package developed leverage national demographic environmental datasets made available U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. package offers canned functions extract process Census block group EJSCREEN ACS data buffered areas surrounding user-provided sf geographies. Users can request different buffer distances GIS inclusion methods. Moreover, buffers can distance-based land (.e. drawing circles around lat/longs) water (leveraging NHDPlus network measure /downstream). secondary interactive mapping function, useful preliminary analytical exploration, also included.

title: EJSCREEN batch tool
text: can install EJSCREENbatch GitHub following:
code: # requires devtools to install install.packages('devtools') library(devtools)  # install from repository install_github('USEPA/EJSCREENbatch') library(EJSCREENbatch)

title: EJSCREEN batch tool
text: visual overview package, highlighting input types, primary data sources, examples output graphics. Three primary data types can input: coordinates, NHDplus common identifiers (ComIDs), shape files (linestrings, polygons). package offers two buffering methods can accept multiple buffer distances time. user can chose output summary plots tables addition returned raw dataframe. Additional documentation demonstration leverage package’s functional available vignette directory. EJSCREENbatch_overview_single_slide

title: EJSCREEN batch tool
text: United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) GitHub project code provided “” basis user assumes responsibility use. EPA relinquished control information longer responsibility protect integrity , confidentiality, availability information. reference specific commercial products, processes, services service mark, trademark, manufacturer, otherwise, constitute imply endorsement, recommendation favoring EPA. EPA seal logo shall used manner imply endorsement commercial product activity EPA United States Government.

title: EJSCREEN batch tool
text: project covered MIT license.

what: Primary function that performs EJ/demographic screening. — EJfunction
title: Primary function that performs EJ/demographic screening. — EJfunction
text: Primary function performs EJ/demographic screening.

title: Primary function that performs EJ/demographic screening. — EJfunction
code: EJfunction(LOI_data, data_year = NULL, buffer = NULL, raster = T, state = NULL)

title: Primary function that performs EJ/demographic screening. — EJfunction
text: LOI_data Required. Location interest. Location data must SF object undergo screening analysis. data_year Option EJSCREEN (corresponding ACS) data vintage return. Default 2023. buffer Distance(s) used create buffers (miles). Default 1, 3, 5 miles points/linestrings 0 miles polygons. raster Block raster apportioning buffer? Default T. set false, uses EJSCREEN's block approach. state User can restrict screening particular states. Default screen entire US.

title: Primary function that performs EJ/demographic screening. — EJfunction
text: list containing 2 sublists: (1) LOI-buffer-level screening summary, (2) CBG-level screening summary block groups within affected communities.

what: Produces an interactive map that displays all facilities. — EJMaps
title: Produces an interactive map that displays all facilities. — EJMaps
text: Produces interactive map displays facilities.

title: Produces an interactive map that displays all facilities. — EJMaps
code: EJMaps(   input_data,   indic_option = NULL,   geography = NULL,   threshold = 80,   facil_name = NULL )

title: Produces an interactive map that displays all facilities. — EJMaps
text: input_data Required. Screening object returned EJFunction() call. indic_option EJSCREEN indicators display? Options 'total','environmental','demographic'. Default 'total'. geography National state percentiles used map? Options 'state' 'US' (default). threshold Percentile threshold map coloring. Default 80. facil_name Column name LOI input data denoting LOI name. String .

title: Produces an interactive map that displays all facilities. — EJMaps
text: list containing leaflet map object(s).

title: Produces an interactive map that displays all facilities. — EJMaps
code: maps <- EJMaps(input_data = z, geography = 'US', save.option = F) #> Error in EJMaps(input_data = z, geography = "US", save.option = F): unused argument (save.option = F)

title: Support function to call EJSCREEN API — EJSCREENBufferAPI

title: Support function to call EJSCREEN API — EJSCREENBufferAPI
text: input_data facility location data sf data.frame (point, (multi-)linestring, (multi-)polygon). dist numeric value designate buffer distance miles.

title: Support function to call EJSCREEN API — EJSCREENBufferAPI
text: tidy data.frame
